 The contradiction of free will is actually something I misunderstood for a quite a while but now I understand it better. The way you view it is that since God knows our every move that means it must all be predetermined, right? If I were to flip a coin and God already knew it would land on heads, then that means it must have been fate that it land on heads correct? This is actually not true. Just because God already knew what side the coin would land on doesn't mean that it was fate that it land on that side although it would appear that way to us. God would be unconstrained by time though. So he could travel to the future to see what side the coin landed on and then return back to our time and tell us that it will land on heads. That way fate didn't play a role and God was still all knowing. The same would be true for a human that could travel through time. He would be able to predict the outcome of every football game for the rest of time and most people would probably think that he rigged the games or that he found a way to determine what fate had in store for the teams, but of course neither would be true.
 
 The only place where being all knowing and free will contradict is in God himself. If God already knows everything that he is going to do then he cannot have free will to change what he is going to do. However, God is all powerful as well which means that he is able to have free will if he wants it. This is a contradiction but it is on a Godly level so we cannot even know if this is a true contradiction or not since God may not be binded by time or need to do things in a particular order as we are made to do here on Earth.
